title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are significant examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations and provide a unique opportunity to illustrate the history of the Cold War, arms race, and ICBM development. The National Park System lacks a unit specifically commemorating the Cold War. The National Park System lacks a unit specifically commemorating the Cold War. The purposes of this Act are to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system, highlighting its historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace and the broader context of the Cold War. This Act aims to complement interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system's historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established in South Dakota as a unit of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities depicted on a map from September 1998. The map of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is available for public inspection at National Park Service offices. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor boundary adjustments. The site will be administered in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary may acquire land within the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Cooperative agreements can be made with public and private entities to implement the Act. Coordination with the Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State is required to ensure compliance with treaties. The Secretary can acquire land for the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Prohibited acquisitions include contaminated land and land in South Dakota, which can only be acquired by donation or exchange. A General Management Plan is required. The Secretary can acquire land for the historic site through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. A General Management Plan must be prepared within 3 years of funds availability, including evaluating locations for visitor and administrative facilities within specified areas on the map. The Secretary can modify the boundary of the historic site to include a selected visitor facility and administrative site. Coordination with Badlands National Park is required for appropriate administrative and management functions. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the implementation of the Act, with the Air Force required to transfer funds for the maintenance of the historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program's funds for resource preservation and treaty compliance remain unaffected by this Act.
